questions.text: What is the ideal site of placement of the instrument shown below when it is being used for feeding purposes?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nasogastric/Ryle's tube. The ideal location for an NG feeding tube is postpyloric to decrease the risk of aspiration.

The ideal location for an NG tube placed for suction is within the stomach because placement past the pylorus can cause damage to the duodenum. 

Nasogastric tubes play a standard role in treating intestinal obstruction and can also be used to provide nutritional support. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method.
 
NEX method:
  • The tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Approximate length to be inserted: 55cm

Ideally, Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • An abdominal X-ray is the best way to confirm the location of the tube

The ideal location for an NG tube placed for suction is within the stomach because placement past the pylorus can cause damage to the duodenum. The ideal location for an NG feeding tube is postpyloric to decrease the risk of aspiration.

Indications for NG tube:

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in acid-induced diarrhoea that is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions 
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Contraindications for NG tube:

  • Absolute:
    • Severe midface trauma
    • Recent nasal surgery
    • Basilar skull fractures
  • Relative:
    • Coagulation abnormality
    • Caustic ingestion
    • Esophageal trauma/ obstruction
    • Esophageal varices
    • Recent banding of oesophagal varices
    • Anastomoses in the stomach and oesophagus

Approximate length of the tube: 120-125 cm

Markings indicating traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

  • 40 cm - Traversed cardia of stomach
  • 50 cm - Traversed body of stomach
  • 60 cm - Traversed pylorus
  • 70 cm - Traversed duodenum

questions.text: A surgeon working in a community health centre notices that the following suture material shown in the image is the only suture available in stock for use. In which of the following conditions is this suture material not useful?
questions.solution:
The suture material shown in the image is plain catgut which is a yellowish absorbable suture material and cannot be used in procedures like hernia repair that require prolonged support.

Plain catgut:

  • It is made of collagen derived from healthy sheep or cattle. 
  • It is absorbed by Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 7–10 days.
  • It is used to ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas, and other tissues that heal rapidly. The tensile strength is lost within 7–10 days and shows marked patient variability.

Contraindications: Not for use in tissues that heal slowly and require prolonged support. Synthetic absorbable sutures are superior in this case.

questions.text: You are an intern observing a surgery where the stones from the bile duct are removed. The instrument given below is used. Name the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is Desjardins choledocholithotomy forceps. It is used for the removal of stones from the common bile duct.

This is a long and slender instrument. The shaft is curved and there is a fenestra at the tip. It does not have a lock hence, accidental damage to CBD mucosa or crushing of the CBD stone is avoided.

Other options: 

Option A: Lane tissue-holding forceps have a stout and thick distal blade, with an oval fenestra in each blade. It has a lock in the proximal part. It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option B: Kocher forceps have an opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used for holding ribs during rib dissection and for holding the resected bowel.

Option D: Lister sinus forceps are used for draining pus from the abscess cavity in Hilton's method. Initially used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity. It has a long straight blade with serrations in the tip.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a chronic alcoholic presented to the emergency room following two episodes of hematemesis and is currently hypotensive. The surgical resident on duty tries to control the bleeding with the instrument shown in the below image. Identify this instrument?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Minnesota tube.

The given clinical scenario i.e chronic alcoholic with haematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding, in which temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades.

Minnesota tube:This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents. It has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes - namely,

  • Gastric aspiration port
  • Oesophageal aspiration port
  • Gastric balloon port
  • Oesophageal balloon port

Protocol-based management of esophageal varices is given below:

Other options:

Option A- Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port as shown below.

Option C- Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon. Below is the image showing various balloon tamponades.

Option D- Ewald tube is a stomach tube used in the removal of poisons through gastric lavage. It has only one aspiration port for the stomach as shown below.

questions.text: The following drain is placed after mastectomy. Identify the type of drain.
questions.solution:
The Romo Vac drain, depicted in the image, is a closed type of drain commonly used after mastectomy.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely collect the air or fluids that may accumulate. This enhances wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains are prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries. Drains can be -

  • Open - They are based on the principle of gravity 
  • Semi-open - Their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed - They carry out their actions through suction

Suction drains are commonly used in chest, breast, abdominal, thyroid, and plastic surgeries. They remove intraperitoneal secretions, anastomotic leaks, and blood from hemorrhage at the surgical site. Romo Vac drain is a negative suction drain closed drain kept in the subcutaneous tissue. Romo Vac drain is indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. 

Special types of drains:

  • Chest drains are connected to an underwater seal to aid the exit of air from the pleural cavity. They are used in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, and hemothorax. 
  • After surgical exploration of the bile duct, the sphincter of Oddi goes into spasm. To facilitate drainage of bile, a T tube may be used. 

Drain insertion site care: The site of insertion of the drain is kept clean by drying and patting the drain insertion site with a clean towel after bath. The dressing is changed daily with folded gauze pieces placed below and above the drain site. 

Removal of drains: The catheter at the site is milked for residual collections. It is then clamped and the suture holding the catheter is cut. The tube is then gently pulled out and any clots at the perforation end are removed. The time of removal of drains for various conditions is as given below. 

  • Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 
  • In a mastectomy, a drain is placed for 5 days to collect serous collections.
  • Drains used to cover the colorectal anastomoses are placed for 5-7 days.
  • Common bile duct T-tube drains are usually placed for 10 days.
  • Drains for infections are removed when the infection subsides or when the content of the drain is minimal.

After the drain is removed, a folded gauze is placed over the drain insertion area. The dressing can be removed after 24 hours. The patient may be given an antibiotic ointment to apply over the area for a week.

questions.text: Identify the brace given below and its use.

choices.text: Anterior spinal hyperextension brace, Dorso-lumbar injury
Sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization brace, cervical spine injury

questions.solution:
The given image shows a sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization (SOMI) brace which is used for cervical spine injuries.

The SOMI brace contains a rigid anterior chest piece connected to rigid shoulder supports by straps across the patient’s back. The mandibular support can be removed during eating. The brace provides good restriction to flexion.

It is indicated in relatively stable injuries to the lower cervical spine, postoperatively for patients with questionable fixation, or in the treatment of cervicothoracic injuries.

 

Other options:

Option A: Scoliosis and kyphosis can be managed with the Milwaukee brace, also known as a cervical-thoracic-lumbosacral orthosis (CTLSO). It contains a pelvic girdle (pelvic mold), bars (superstructures), and a combination of corrective slings and pads that attach to the superstructure. The pelvic girdle locks onto the waist roll and reduces lumbar lordosis, which helps in kyphosis correction.

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace.

Option B: Anterior spinal hyperextension brace(ASHE brace) is used in dorsolumbar spinal injury. A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. It is shown in the image below.

Option C: Taylor brace is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.

questions.text:
A woman who came to the ENT Outpatient department was tested with the instrument given below for impaired hearing. Which of the following tests can be performed with this instrument?
  1. Weber’s test
  2. Schwabach’s test
  3. Threshold Tone Decay Test
  4. Gelle’s test
  5. Short Increment Sensitivity Index
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is a tuning fork. Weber’s test, Schwabach’s test, and Gelle’s test can be done with a tuning fork.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Weber’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is better heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • It is reported as normal when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralised to the worst ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness it is lateralized to the better ear.

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner, but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: The Test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Gelle’s test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of increased air pressure in the ear canal on hearing. Normally, when air pressure is increased in the ear canal by Siegel’s speculum, it pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards. This raises the intralabyrinthine pressure and causes immobility of the basilar membrane and decreased hearing. But, no change in hearing is observed when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. Gelle’s test is positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss.

The threshold tone decay test is a measure of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute, but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. A decay of more than 25 dB is diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion.

The Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI )test distinguishes between a cochlear and a retrocochlear lesion. Patients with cochlear lesions distinguish smaller changes in the intensity of pure tone better. In this test, a continuous tone is presented 20 dB above the threshold and sustained for about 2 min. Every 5 seconds, the tone is increased by 1 dB and 20 such blips are presented. The patient indicates the blips heard. In conductive deafness, the SISI score is seldom more than 15%. It is 70%-100% in cochlear deafness and 0%-20% in retrocochlear (nerve) deafness.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is Eves’ tonsil snare. 

Eves’ tonsil snare is used for tonsillectomy and the wire used is number 25 SWG. After the tonsil has been dissected to its lower pole, the snare is passed around the tonsil to engage the pedicle and then firmly closed. It crushes and cuts the pedicle thereby minimizing bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Negus knot tier is also an instrument that is used in tonsillectomy.  It helps to carry the ligature knot till the tip of the artery forceps which holds the vessel and then tie it.


Option B: Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor - Dissection of the tonsil is done by one end and the other end serves to retract the anterior pillar for inspecting the tonsillar fossa to locate any bleeding points.


Option C: Denis Browne’s tonsil holding forceps is used to hold the tonsil during dissection method tonsillectomy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with swelling and pain in the right leg, which is worse at night. Pain relieves on NSAIDs. You suspect osteoid osteoma. Which of the following instruments is used to remove the entire nidus of the osteoma?
questions.solution:
The instrument used to remove the entire nidus of osteoid osteoma is the curette shown in image B.

A curette is used for curetting a cavity in bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of the fracture. It is used in enchondroma, giant cell tumors, tubercular cavities of the bone, and osteomyelitis.

The instruments in the image are:

  • Image A: Periosteal elevator
  • Image B: Curette
  • Image C: Osteotome
  • Image D: Bone gouge

Osteoid osteoma is a benign neoplasm most often seen in young men. A typical patient presents with pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or NSAIDs. Plain radiographs are sufficient to make the diagnosis, but CT is the best technique to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. Treatment includes medical management with long-term anti-inflammatory medications, percutaneous radiofrequency ablation, and surgical treatment. Surgical treatment involves removal of the entire nidus, this can be accomplished by curettage or en bloc resection.

Image A is the periosteal elevator. It is used to elevate the periosteum as nerves, and vessels are generally on this plane, and once this has been elevated the surgeon is on a safer plane.

Image C represents an osteotome that can be used to cut bone while performing an osteotomy. An osteotome has both sides beveled.

Image D is bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting on round bone surfaces or making round holes in the bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: Name  the instrument given below is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Czerny's retractor. Czerny’s Retractor is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

Option A: Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving a maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Option C: Double hook Retractor is used:

  • To retract skin flap for excision of sebaceous cyst.
  • During venesection for retraction of skin.
  • During tracheostomy for retraction of skin and thyroid isthmus.

Option D: Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

questions.text: All of the following are the uses of the instrument  given in the image except______

choices.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
To measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Simpson’s uterine sound. It is not used in the fallopian tube recanalization procedure.

Simpson’s uterine sound is a 30 cm-long angulated instrument. It has a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other. The angulation of the instrument accommodates for flexion of the uterus

Uses:

  • To measure uterine cavity and cervical length
  • To diagnose cervical stenosis
  • To sound a polyp, IUCD, or uterine septum
  • To break uterine adhesions in Asherman syndrome
  • To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and the site at which it is used for taking samples.

choices.text: Ayre's spatula used at the squamocolumnar junction
Ayre's spatula used at the endocervix
Cytobrush used at the squamocolumnar junction

questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is a cytobrush which is used to take samples from the endocervix for a Pap smear. Ayre’s spatula is used to take samples from the squamocolumnar junction.

The instruments used for a pap smear are summarized in the image below.


The Pap/ Papanicolaou test is used for screening cervical neoplasia. The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation but can be done at any other time as well. 24-48 hours prior to the test, patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications. The Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination, because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol. After fixing the slide for 30 minutes, it is air dried and stained with Pap stain or short stain.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the instrument given below.

choices.text: Palmer's point is the preferred entry site in high-risk patients.
Potential for bowel injury is lesser in the technique using this instrument.
Used for creating pneumoperitoneum by closed method.
Preferred in patients with previous abdominal surgeries.

questions.solution:
The image is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The open method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound. The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar is inserted and anchored, and a pneumoperitoneum is created.

The safest site of entry in high-risk patients is the left upper quadrant, better known as Palmer's point. This site is 3 cm below the left costal margin in the midclavicular line. It is rarely affected by adhesions.

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The image below shows a Veress needle.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:

choices.text: Delivery of occipitotransverse position in platypelloid pelvis
Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
Outlet forceps used to provide traction force

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is an outlet forceps used to provide traction force.

 Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • The fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • The fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • The sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps are used in correcting asynctilism.

Option B: Barton forceps are used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.

Option C: Piper forceps have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to you with complaints of pain over the nose after falling from height. On examination, there is a fracture of the nasal septum. Which of the following instruments would you use during the surgery for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of nasal septum fracture. The instrument used during surgery for this condition is Asch forceps as seen in the image 2.

Other options:

Option A: Luc’s forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

Option C: Tilley’s forceps is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are used in myomectomy?
questions.solution:
The instruments used in myomectomy are Bonney's myomectomy clamp (Image 2) and Doyen Myoma Screw (Image 4).

Bonney's myomectomy clamp is used in open myomectomy. It has two sets of finger grips and a locking ratchet mechanism. It helps in controlling hemorrhage and providing a blood-free environment while performing myomectomy. The clamp is usually applied from the pubic end of the abdominal wound, gripping the round ligaments that contain uterine vessels.

Doyen Myoma Screw is also used in open myomectomy. The handle present in this can be used to distinguish it from a laparoscopic myoma screw which also has a similar tip. It helps in enucleation.

Other images:

Image 1: Sim's curette is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage. It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

Image 3: The episiotomy scissor is bent on the edge. It has a blunt tip that goes inside the vagina. It is used to perform episiotomy during delivery.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

questions.text: A patient is prepared for a minor procedure in the ophthalmology outpatient department. The following instruments are assembled in the tray. Which of the following glands is involved in the pathology for which this procedure is performed?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments represents the chalazion set which is used to perform incision and curettage of a chalazion.

The chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation. Excessive tightening of the screw can lead to pressure necrosis. The solid blade is placed externally on the skin and the ring-shaped blade is on the inner conjunctival surface.

A chalazion scoop/curette is another instrument specific to the incision and curettage of a chalazion. It has a small round cup-shaped tip with sharp margins attached to a narrow handle. It is used to scoop out the contents of the chalazion and curette the base after making a vertical incision opening up the wall of the chalazion from its palpebral surface.

A chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of the Meibomian gland. A chalazion may be single or multiple. They may reduce in size, but the complete spontaneous resolution does not occur. Treatment of chalazion includes injection of intralesional triamcinolone or curettage.

Sometimes, the chalazion may become secondarily infected and form a hordeolum internum. This is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct. It presents with a swelling similar to a chalazion, but more inflamed with pus pointing on the conjunctival surface. It can be treated conservatively with oral antibiotics and hot fomentation or with an incision and drainage. An image of hordeolum internum is shown below.

Other options :

Options A and D: The gland of Wolfring and the gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands and are not involved in a chalazion.

Option B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the intrauterine device shown below?

choices.text: It has silver added to the copper wire
It can be used as an emergency contraceptive
It has a lifespan of 10 years

questions.solution:
The given image shows the intrauterine contraceptive device, multi-load copper 250. It can be used for emergency contraception.

Mechanism of action:

Once placed inside the uterine cavity, the multi-load copper 250 device acts as a foreign body and induces inflammatory changes in the endometrium. Copper released from the device cause enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrium. It increases uterine contractility leading to the expulsion of the fertilized egg from the fallopian tube into the endometrium before the development of chorionic villi and ultimately, causes failure of implantation. The fertilized egg is then engulfed by the macrophages recruited due to the inflammatory changes. In addition, the device hinders the migration of the sperm.

The lifespan of multi-load copper 250 is about 3-5 years.

Other options:

Option A: Nova T has silver added to the copper wire which prolongs its lifespan to 5 years. 

Option C: Copper T 380 A (Paraguard) is effective as a contraceptive for up to 10 years, and is shown in the image below.

 Option D: Mirena IUCD contains levonorgestrel 52 mg, and is shown below

Other important intrauterine devices are progestasert having 38 mg of progesterone and levonova containing 60mg of levonorgestrel (LNG).

questions.text: In the ophthalmology practical examination, the external examiner asks you to identify the given object. Choose the correct answer.

choices.text: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
Singh and Worst's iris claw lens

questions.solution:
The image depicts Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL). It is the most commonly used ACIOL.

Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of the anterior chamber. These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy. Thus, they are currently used only for correction of aphakia in cases where posterior chamber IOLs cannot be used (eg: rupture of posterior capsule).

questions.text: A 56-year-old male sustained a fracture of the neck of femur and he was planned for replacement surgery. Identify the prosthesis in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Austin-Moore prosthesis. The Austin-Moore prosthesis is used for hemiarthroplasty in the neck of femur fracture in elderly individuals. 

The Austin-Moore prosthesis has a head, neck, and stem. The stem has a hole to which the hook of the extractor can be attached. It helps in removing the prosthesis. There are two fenestrations in the stem which are for bone growth and fixing the prosthesis. It can be used without cement since its usage makes the removal difficult. 

The below image shows Austin Moore's prosthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Thompson prosthesis is used in hemiarthroplasty to replace the head of the femur. It is specially indicated in cases where the neck of the femur is absorbed. It can be used with or without cement.

The below image shows the radiograph image of Thompson's prosthesis.

Option C: Charnley's prosthesis is a total hip prosthesis used to replace the acetabulum and the head of the femur. it contains a polyethylene acetabulum cup and a steel head with a diameter of 22 mm. The radiograph image is shown below.

Option D: Muller's prosthesis is also a total hip prosthesis but the size of the head differs (32 mm) and the stem is available in different thicknesses.
